column4: does anyone know a command to open two xterm sessions simultaneously and execute a script in each of them?
xterm -e foo & xterm -e bar
that doesnt seem to open them simultaneously, it does it sequentially
Did you use '&' or '&&' ?
is there a difference?
Yes.
What is the exact command you ran?
xterm -e /media/F5B6-D9E4/pythongame/newapp/gameServer1.py & sleep 1 & xterm -e /media/F5B6-D9E4/pythongame/newapp/newclient.py
i need both of those scripts to run at the same time, but i want to give the first script a second to initialize
The "sleep 1" in that is doing nothing, as using '&' means that it is also running in the background. So all three commands are running at the same time.
ok that makes sense now. so how would i start the second script a second after the first? im trying to keep this in one command so i can alias it.
foo & sleep 1; bar &
alright ill try it
what is the last & doing?
Making it so that you can run commands after that in the same shell.
so if these scripts are running in the background, how do i stop them? will they automatically stop when i close the terminal?
Yes (though the scripts can be made to continue even after the terminal is closed if you wanted them to).
i tried your command with xterm and tried it with gnome-terminal but it isnt working the way i would like in either
What is happening and what would you like to happen instead?
im just looking for a way to emulate that command in xterm (ie without tabs)
with this command it opens the first tab and executes the script, waits a second, then opens the second tab and executes the second script
nevermind, getting rid of the "sleep 1" seems to fix things. not sure why that was causing a problem.
